title: David Yang Shu
text:
Postdoctoral Associate

MIT Energy Initiative & Shin Group | ChemE | MIT 


 Hey there!
I am a postdoctoral associate at MIT working on the nonlinear optimal design of carbon capture units under uncertainty and reducing emissions from hard-to-abate industries. My research spans environmental life-cycle assessment, process optimization, and sustainable system design, with applications in carbon capture and storage technologies and the broader energy transition.
In my doctoral studies at ETH Zurich (Switzerland), I investigated the design and operation of net-zero energy systems employing multi-criterial optimization to evaluate trade-offs between economic and environmental objectives. I further applied bilevel optimization to model market interactions in the energy transition.
In my research, I have contributed to the Horizon 2020 project  DMX™ Demonstration in Dunkirk (3D) by performing life-cycle assessments for full-scale CCUS supply chains. I also evaluated the sustainability of carbon dioxide transport in the Swiss demonstration project  DemoUpCARMA, in which we captured and transported CO2 all the way fom Switzerland to Iceland for geological storage in basaltic rock.
Interested in my research? Let me know, I am happy chat!

An Ecosystem of Carbon Dioxide Removal Reviews - Part 1: Direct Air CO2 Capture and Storage.


CCS
industry
LCA


We have contributed to this review on direct air CO₂ capture and storage, a key technology for carbon dioxide removal that will be essential in achieving and sustaining net-zero emissions. The review synthesizes current knowledge on DACCS, covering technology status, technoeconomic and environmental performance, policy, equity, public perception, and monitoring. It highlights that large-scale deployment of DACCS will require sustained government support, akin to the subsidies that enabled renewable energy expansion.



Mijndert Van der Spek, André Bardow, Chad M. MIT PSE Seminar: Environmental life-cycle assessment for sustainable energy systems


news


Join my talk on life-cycle assessment for sustainable energy systems at the MIT PSE seminar on October 9, 2025. In this talk, I will share insights from two demonstrator projects that explore the environmental impacts of carbon capture and storage supply chains. We further discuss how integrating process-level environmental assessments into broader system-level analyses can reveal system-wide knock-on effects. Checkout the other talks we have organized for you in the MIT PSE seminar series.



David Yang Shu

Transition pathways to electrified chemical production within sector-coupled national energy systems


energy systems
industry
optimization


We investigated how the chemical industry can transition to net-zero emissions within a sector-coupled national energy system. Our findings show that electrification of chemical production happens later than in other sectors, beginning with methanol and progressing through ammonia, olefins, and aromatics. During the transition, a partially electrified, diversified chemical industry provides system flexibility and supports the integration of intermittent renewable energy.



Patricia Mayer, Florian Joseph Baader, David Yang Shu, Ludger Leenders, Christian Zibunas, Stefano Moret, André Bardow


2025-07-03













Demonstration of the DMX™ technology for carbon capture and storage in steel production: An environmental assessment


CCS
LCA
industry


We investigated a megatonne-scale CCS supply chain applied to a steel plant. The study, based on detailed data generated in the DMX™ Demonstration in Dunkirk project, finds high life-cycle CCS efficiencies due to the low greenhouse-gas-intensity of local energy supply and efficient offshore transport. However, CCS must be considered within a portfolio of decarbonization strategies.



David Yang Shu, Leidy-Tatiana Vargas-Ibáñez, Guillaume Batôt, Fabrice Devaux, Vania Santos Moreau, Ludger Leenders, André Bardow


2025-06-12

We assess net-zero sector-coupled energy system designs within the planetary boundaries framework for absolute environmental sustainability. Our assessment reveals that transitioning to net-zero reduces many environmental impacts, but may still leave planetary boundaries transgressed.

Flexibility from industrial demand-side management in net-zero sector-coupled national energy systems


energy systems
industry
optimization


Using a generic, process-agnostic model, we determine the value of industrial demand-side management within larger energy systems. We show that demand-side management can reduce total energy system costs by up to 4.4% or 20% of industry-related energy costs. However, the value of demand-side management depends on the system’s flexibility alternatives.



Patricia Mayer, Mario Heer, David Yang Shu, Nik Zielonka, Ludger Leenders, Florian Joseph Baader, André Bardow


2024-07-18













Overcoming the central planner approach – Bilevel optimization of the European energy transition


energy systems
LCA
optimization


We model distributed decision making in the transition to net-zero energy systems via bilevel optimization. By comparing the results of the transition to a model following the central planner approach, we find that neglecting stakeholder representation in energy system models can result in miscalculations of the need for capacity expansion.



David Yang Shu, Christiane Reinert, Jacob Mannhardt, Ludger Leenders, Jannik Lüthje, Alexander Mitsos, André Bardow
